The sweet feeling of upgraded RAM! You're on the right track, and I'm happy to help you squeeze out even more performance from your laptop. Here are some tweaks to help you optimize your laptop's performance:

1. **Close unnecessary programs and background apps**: Many programs run in the background and consume resources without your knowledge. Press the Windows key + R, type "msconfig," and disable any unnecessary startup programs. You can also use the Task Manager (Ctrl + Shift + Esc) to identify and close resource-hungry processes.
2. **Update your operating system and drivers**: Ensure your Windows operating system and drivers are up-to-date, as updates often include performance optimizations. Go to Settings > Update & Security > Windows Update and check for updates.
3. **Disable unnecessary system animations**: Animations can consume system resources. Press the Windows key + I, go to System > Advanced system settings > Performance settings, and adjust the visual effects to your liking.
4. **Adjust your power settings**: Your laptop's power settings might be throttling performance to conserve battery life. Go to Settings > Power & sleep > Power options, and adjust the power plan to "High performance" or create a custom plan that suits your needs.
5. **Optimize your disk usage**: Low disk space can slow down your laptop. Check your disk usage by going to File Explorer > This PC > Devices and drives. Consider deleting unnecessary files, emptying the Recycle Bin, and uninstalling unused programs.
6. **Defragment your hard drive (if you're using a traditional hard drive)**: If you're still using a traditional hard drive (not an SSD), defragmentation can improve performance. Go to File Explorer > This PC > Devices and drives, right-click on the drive, and select "Properties." Then, click on the "Tools" tab and click "Defragment and Optimize Drives."
7. **Consider upgrading your storage to an SSD**: If you're still using a traditional hard drive, upgrading to a Solid-State Drive (SSD) can significantly boost your laptop's performance. SSDs are much faster and more efficient than traditional hard drives.
8. **Monitor your system's temperature**: Overheating can throttle your laptop's performance. Use software like SpeedFan or HWMonitor to monitor your system's temperature. Ensure your laptop's vents are clear of obstructions, and consider using a cooling pad if necessary.
9. **Update your graphics drivers**: If you're using a dedicated graphics card, update your graphics drivers to the latest version. Outdated drivers can cause performance issues.
10. **Consider upgrading your laptop's cooling system**: If your laptop is prone to overheating, consider upgrading its cooling system. This might involve cleaning the vents, replacing the thermal paste, or installing a more efficient cooling system.
11. **Limit background apps' resource usage**: Some apps might be consuming resources in the background without your knowledge. Use the Task Manager to identify and limit the resource usage of these apps.
12. **Disable unnecessary system services**: Some system services might be running in the background and consuming resources. Press the Windows key + R, type "services.msc," and disable any unnecessary services.

By implementing these tweaks, you should see an improvement in your laptop's performance. However, if you're still experiencing issues, it might be worth considering upgrading your laptop's processor or graphics card (if possible) or investing in a new laptop with better specifications.
